products.title: CSS: The Definitive Guide, 5th Edition
products.opinion: ... have I read it completely? Of course not! It has over 1000 pages. But I'm on it. I'm actually planning to read it cover to cover, and I'm somewhere on page 240, but I keep reaching for it to look up a particular chapter. It's a treasure trove, and also lovingly and humorously written. A must have.
products.alt: The cover shows the title and authors Eric Meyer and Estelle Weyl, as well as a lifelike illustration of three salmon

products.title: JavaScript Cookbook, 3rd Edition
products.opinion: By far my favourite Javascript book and the one I recommend to anyone with basic knowledge. At no point did I have the feeling of being left behind, the code examples are simple and true to life and wonderfully comprehensible. There's but one foo-bar-baz example (and I think it got in there by accident), which I really appreciate. The book even shows a sense of humour. I really enjoyed reading it and I always have it near me to look something up.
products.alt: The cover displays the book title and authors Adam D. Scott, Matthew MacDonald and Shelley Powers, as well as a lifelike illustration of a little egret (Egretta garzetta).

products.title: Every Layout
products.opinion: A book by two individuals that share a deep understanding of the web in general and CSS in particular. I love how it's written and how much it teaches me. It gets regular updates and provides access to invaluable code.
products.alt: The black and white cover says 'Every Layout - Relearn CSS layout by example. 3rd edition', with the authors' names Heydon Pickering and Andy Bell below.

products.title: The Linux Command Line
products.opinion: This is one of the books that was a real eye-opener for me. I have always used the command line very dubiously and without much background knowledge, and this book has opened up a world for me. I really enjoyed reading it, it's entertaining and doesn't get unnecessarily complex at any point.
products.alt: Cover image: A robot happily dumping Linux knowledge into its mouth -  it looks like dozens of scraps of paper with 'grep', 'chown' or 'cat' written on them, among other things.

products.title: Inclusive Components
products.opinion: Inclusive Components is all about accessible patterns like accordions, dropdowns, sliders and modals. I use Heydon's component solution for cards in literally every project.
products.alt: 'Inclusive Components', framed by a electrical circuit illutstration that illuminates a light bulb. Subtitle: Accessible web interfaces, piece by piece. The author is Heydon Pickering.

products.title: Practical Accessibility
products.opinion: Great in depth accessibility course by Sara Soueidan. I learned an incredible amount and felt an urgent desire to immediately revamp all my existing websites.
products.alt: Practical accessibilty.today with Sara Soueidan. A self paced, get-right-down-to-it video course designed to demystify web accessibility and equip you with the knowledge you need to create more accessible websites and web applications today.

products.title: CSS for JS
products.opinion: Very long, detailed, interactive and comprehensive course made by Josh Comeau. It's made especially for JavaScript developers that started off on a wrong foot with CSS, which doesn't apply to me at all, but it's nevertheless very worthwhile.
products.alt: A gradient from yellow to red, saying CSS for JavaScript developers in uppercase latters. The author is Josh Comeau.

products.title: You Don't Know JS Yet: Get Started
products.opinion: Another Javascript book that I enjoyed very much. Kyle Simpson explains the basic workings of Javascript with comprehensible code examples. The book was crucial for me to understand concepts like closure, prototypes and scope. All books can be read for free on GitHub.
products.alt: 'You Don't Know JS Yet' written between two simplified black illustrations of faces that seem to scream at each other, somehing that took me very long to see. 'Get started' is the first book of a series by Kyle Simpson. On the bottom are some chess figures, some of them knocked over.

products.title: learnjavascript.online
products.opinion: This course comes with an interactive environment. The short lessons are directly followed by challenges. Exercising anywhere is possible with a special flashcards app, based on your progress. It took me ages to understand Javascript. This course definitely helped me with that.

products.title: Git for Humans
products.opinion: I understand Git a little better  thanks to this book. Like all A book apart publications it's nice and short.
products.alt: A book apart cover in dark red, displaying author David Demaree's 'Git for Humans' in white letters.
